description: Analysis of cellular and systems-level human physiology with an emphaisis on clinical applications. Particular emphasis is on mechanisms of function in the neural and cardiovascular systems.
name: ENG PRINC OF HUMAN PHYSI

values.comments:
This class teaches analysis of cellular and systems-level human physiology with
an emphasis on clinical applications with a particular emphasis is on mechanisms of
function in the neural and cardiovascular systems.
This class explores physiology primarily with calculus. This class covers many
theoretical concepts, but overall students thought the material was “stimulating” and
“interesting.” Most of the material was taught through PowerPoints. Students reported
learning a lot from this course, but complained about difficulty synthesizing material due
to it being difficult figuring out which slides were most important to study for exams. A
distinguishing feature of this class is the emphasis on guest lectures, which students said
had its pros and cons. As one student puts it, “The course is built from multiple guest
lecturers who are researchers and physicians at Penn or HUP, who talk about various
sections of physiology. Sometimes the course feels a bit disjointed due to the different
lecture styles, but overall, the lecturers stimulated my interest. The exams were all
created by one professor, so they felt fair.” Students complained about different lecturers
going at completely different speeds and how assignments did not match up well to the
lectures.
Mauck, the main professor, teaches the three main “chunks” of the class and
students state that his accessibility made this class one of their favorites at Penn.
Students reported that Mauck answered any emails to him within hours regularly.
The class is meant for third year bioengineering students. Students felt as if this
class was difficult but manageable, especially if you work in groups that can work
together to decipher the at-times confusing homework assignments. Students also
complained about the difficulty for studying for exams with a lot of dense material from
different lecturers and unclear direction on what material was most important to study.
One student stated, “The tests generally wound up being a lot easier than the material the
lecturers spoke about, but you could never be sure so you had to try to study everything.”
